Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Dimethylsulfoniopropionate (DMSP) accounts for up to 10% of the carbon fixed by marine phytoplankton in surface waters of the ocean and is the precursor to the potent anti-greenhouse gas dimethylsulfide (DMS), the largest natural source of sulfur to the atmosphere. Two competing pathways for DMSP metabolism operate in marine microbial communities. Most of the DMSP is processed by marine bacteria through the "demethylation" pathway, which leads to formation of methanethiol (MeSH) and other sulfur compounds. A smaller portion is metabolized via the "cleavage" pathway to DMS, resulting in sulfur emissions to the atmosphere. The point at which DMSP is directed to one of these pathways, referred to as "the bacterial switch", represents one of the critical regulatory points in the global sulfur cycle. Based upon recent discoveries of the genes necessary for these pathways, this research will examine the physiological and biochemical basis the bacterial switch in the model marine bacterium, Ruegeria pomeroyi. Research will examine the enzymes of the pathways to further understand how they function in cells. Other environmental and physiological controls of DMSP metabolism will be characterized in whole cells. Four roles will be specifically tested: DMSP as a carbon and sulfur source, as a compatible solute, and as an antioxidant. In addition, many of the genes of the demethylation pathway are widespread in terrestrial and other habitats where DMSP is not abundant and have been hypothesized to function in methionine metabolism. This potential role will also be tested. In conclusion, bacterial DMSP metabolism plays a fundamental role in the global sulfur cycle. This research seeks to understand why the bacteria metabolize DMSP.


Broader Impacts: The broader impacts of the project include the training of two doctoral students and one postdoctoral research associate in the departments of Microbiology and Marine Sciences at the University of Georgia and providing research opportunities and mentoring for one undergraduate student per year. Students will obtain interdisciplinary training in microbial physiology, microbial ecology, enzymology and environmental sciences. Outreach activities at local elementary and high schools will emphasize prokaryotic diversity, decomposition and the carbon cycle, photosynthetic bacteria, and the role of bacteria in forming the earth's atmosphere. It will provide students opportunities for hands on work with modern techniques of molecular microbial ecology. By improving our knowledge of the microbial control of the evolution of DMS to the atmosphere, this research will provide understanding how these processes will respond to the predicted climate changes as well as potential opportunities for mitigation of global climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Algae in the ocean produce large amounts of a compound called dimethylsulfoniopropionate or DMSP. The DMSP is transformed by the algae themselves or marine bacteria into either dimethylsulfide (also called DMS) or methane thiol. A small portion of the DMS  escapes from seawater, where it is a major source of sulfur to the upper atmosphere and stimulates cloud formation. Because cloud formation leads to cooling of the earth's surface, DMS is sometimes called an anti-greenhouse gas. The research described herein studied how and why bacteria transform DMSP to either DMS or methane thiol. Thus, this research provides basic insight into how DMS is produced, degraded, or released into the atmosphere.

Regarding the how, these studies demonstrated that marine bacteria possess at least two different strategies for DMSP degradation.  In one strategy, DMSP is rapidly degraded and used as a sulfur source for the bacterium. In addition, large amounts are consumed as carbon and energy sources, producing both DMS and methane thiol at the same time. The bacteria that utilize this strategy contain a specialized enzyme called DmdD for the last step in the degradation pathway. in the second strategy, DMSP is consumed much more slowly, mostly forming methane thiol and very little DMS. These bacteria lack DmdD. Instead, hte enzyme that performs this step of the pathway is shared with other pathways and is much less efficient.

Regarding the why, our studies also examined why bacteria use DMSP or DMS. For instance, sun light is very toxic to bacteria in the ocean because it causes oxidative stress. DMS is a potent scavenger of reactive oxygen species in oxidative stress and could protect the cells.  Does oxidative stress regulate DMS production? To address this question, we constructed a mutant that was more sensitive to oxidative stress. If oxidative stress regulated DMS production, the mutant shoud have made more DMS, but it did not. Thus, oxidative stress did not appear to be a major regulatory factor. Alternatively, methane thiol is an intermediate in sulfur assimilation, and its production might be related to the cells demand for sulfur for amino acid biosynthesis. This idea was supported because DMSP sulfur was used to make amino acids when only very low amounts were provided to cells.  Lastly, do cells make less DMS when they are starved or at low DMSP concentrations?  Because DMS contains a lot of the energy in DMSP, cells might only produce methane thiol when DMSP is not abundant.  However, we found no evidence for this hypothesis as well. thus, it was possible to eliminate several potential rationales for DMSP metabolism in nature.

In addition to these goals, the work had several broader impacts.  First, it provided training in microbial physiology and ecology for undergraduate and graduate students. It also funded field trips for local high school students to the Marine Science Station at Sapelo Island, Georgia.  Lastly, it supported  demonstrations to local fifth graders about microbial diversity.
